newsitem.title: CHINA: China state firm profits top president's agenda.
newsitem.headline: China state firm profits top president's agenda.

text.p: Chinese President Jiang Zemin has set reform of loss-making state firms as a priority this year and the cabinet has put aside $3.6 billion as a reserve fund to re-employ millions made jobless by bankrupt dinosaurs.

"China's state-owned enterprises control the lifeline of the national economy and play a dominant role in national economic development," the People's Daily on Tuesday quoted Jiang, who is also Communist Party chief, as telling deputies to the National People's Congress, or parliament.

The thorny task of reforming loss-making state enterprises -- backbone of China's socialist system -- is the centrepiece of the annual government work report for 1997 by Premier Li Peng that was presented to parliament at the weekend.

Jiang did not hesitate to stress the importance of the market forces introduced to China by his mentor, late paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, in forcing tens of thousands of state-owned firms to make a profit or go under.

State firms, which haemorrhaged money last year when losses skyrocketed 45 percent in the first nine months, faced difficulties, Jiang said. "This has become an outstanding issue in our economic life," he said.
He cited the failure of state firms, cushioned for decades by government subsidies and a state plan, to operate in line with market factors.
"Secondly, they are structurally irrational. The traditional industrial structure and the traditional product mix are no longer suited for the change from a sellers' to a buyers' market," he said.
Competition from a flood of foreign investment and booming rural enterprises was hurting state industry, he said.
"And fourth, owing to historical reasons, state-owned enterprises suffer from too high a debt burden and shoulder too heavy social burdens," he said.
He urged breaking down regional and departmental barriers and an end to unlawful competition -- or protectionism.
Economic tsar, Vice Premier Zhu Rongji, was more direct.
"Bankruptcies should be standardised, mergers should be encouraged," he told deputies.
"Since the majority of industrial products are in over-supply, state-owned enterprises should work hard to restructure instead of building new plants."
Zhu offered a solution to the spectre of mounting unemployment -- anathema to China's communist leaders who fear social unrest could erode their grip on power.
China's State Council, or cabinet, is to set aside 30 billion yuan ($3.6 billion) this year as a reserve fund for re-employment and mergers and bankruptcies of state-owned enterprises, Zhu said.
The funds will be used for re-employment programmes to provide jobs for workers displaced by mergers and bankruptcies.
"Providing conditions for a good settlement of these workers is an important way to help money-losing state enterprises out of their difficulties," Zhu was quoted as saying.
